subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Behaving Strangely in Eclipse
msgSnippet: ... This is not the way we usually use JUnit. Do you have a specific reason for doing it this way? ... When you use the Eclipse test runner, it automatically
messageBody:
hotquietday2 wrote:

> I think this is a JUnit question, but it may be relevant that I'm
> using it within Eclipse:
>
> The main method in my test case looks like this:
>
> public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
> TestCase test = new LogParserTest("testReadFile");
> test.run();
> }

This is not the way we usually use JUnit. Do you have a specific reason
for doing it this way?

> Two strange things are happening:
>
> 1. This is running every test in LogParserTest -- not
> just "testReadFile".

When you use the Eclipse test runner, it automatically collects tests
from your test case class and executes them. It does not run main(). To
run main(), just run your class as a Java application. Your code makes
it look like you want to do just that.

You might want to look at a tutorial. Go to www.diasparsoftware.com and
check out Publications > JUnit: A Starter Guide.

> 2. My TestCase constructor is getting called twice (presumably b/c I
> have two tests. I'm sure these two behaviours are related.

Each test executes in its own instance of the test case class. This is
intentional for test isolation.

> public LogParserTest(String str) throws IOException,
> FileNotFoundException {
> super(str);
> logParser = new SingleLogParser
> ("C:/eclipse/workspace/TestFileIO/test/logs/testLog.txt");
> }

Don't initialize your test objects in the constructor; use setUp() instead.

Read the tutorial I recommend. It will clear a lot up for you.
